scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of ca. 200 items (1 Hollinger box), including 115 letters, 1943-1944, from Beecher Ray Burnett (1922- ?) to his wife, Anita Lester Burnett, written from Greensboro, North Carolina, and San Antonio, Texas, while training in the Army Air Corps, and ca. 75 items of memorabilia pertaining to his service in the Army Air Corps, removed from a scrapbook. Beecher Burnett was born in Roanoke, Virginia, to Abram Delmar Burnett (1882-[1935?]) and Bessie R. Sogren Burnett (1894- ?). He graduated from Jefferson High School, Roanoke, Virginia, in 1940, and then married Anita Lester the same year. He worked for the Norfolk & Western Railway Company until he was inducted into the Armed Forces.

The memorabilia removed from the scrapbook includes: news clippings; war department memoranda; letters of recommendation; Burnett's birth certificate; rosters; forms; a manual "Aviation Student Regulations A.A.F.C.C." Army Air Forces Classification Center, San Antonio, Aviation Cadet Center, San Antonio, Texas; receipts; church bulletins; schedules; Christmas greetings and a Christmas dinner menu and program at San Antonio; a handkerchief; dog tag; post cards and a map of San Antonio, Texas; military patch; tags; and a military pass while Burnett was at the 47th College Training Detachment (Air Crew) Marshall College, Huntington, West Virginia.

The first group of letters were written by Beecher Burnett to Anita Burnett, Roanoke, Virginia, while he was assigned to the 1187 Training Group, 304th Wing, Barrack #438, Squadron "D," Basic Training Center #10, Greensboro, North Carolina. Most of Burnett's letters contain frank expressions of how much he misses his wife, both emotionally and sexually. They also provide an uncensored view of his daily reactions to the army and its routines.

While at Greensboro in 1943, Burnett writes about: receiving his uniform and other gear ([Jul 31]); his need for an iron and other articles (Aug 1); a lecture and film on the gas mask drill, other drilling, and chemical warfare (Aug 2); films on articles of war, military courtesy, and sexual hygiene (Aug 2-3); various tests, warning not to repeat any information from his letters, necessity of her getting a job, and warning her to be faithful and careful around men, frequently repeated in subsequent letters (Aug 5); enjoyment of the day room and library on base, his frantic need to see his wife, and his worry over her answering a "war wives" ad (Aug 8); his efforts to get a pass to meet her in Greensboro, North Carolina (Aug 10); gas drills description (Aug 11); a brief hiatus when he spends some time with his wife in Greensboro (Aug 13-15); on guard duty (Aug 17); description of army skirmishes in the woods (Aug 19); rumors about the "rifle range" experience (Aug 22); expressions of extreme frustration over his wife's absence from him and anxiety about possible unfaithfulness (Aug 22, 23, 24); and life on the "rifle range" (Aug 25-29).

Another gap in the correspondence occurs when his wife, Anita, joins Burnett in Huntington, West Virginia, while he attends the 47th College Training Detachment (Air Crew), U.S. Army Air Forces, Marshall College.

From Huntington, West Virginia, Burnett travels to the Army Air Force Classification Center/San Antonio Aviation Cadet Center in San Antonio, Texas (1943 Nov 28) where he spends a good deal of time being processed and tested mentally and physically as to his ability to join a flight crew (Nov 29-Dec 10). His tendency towards air sickness disqualifies him for flying and he discusses other positions to which he might be assigned (Dec 20). Burnett is re-classified as a non-combatant "pressure chamber technician" which will require one month of training in San Antonio (Dec 30).

Burnett transferred to the 29th Altitude Training Unit (Pre-flight), San Antonio Aviation Cadet Center, at the beginning of 1944 and all of the remaining letters are for that year (1944 Jan 4). Burnett writes about receiving a gift box from Norfolk & Western Railroad Company and going through the tear gas and chlorine gas chambers (Jan 7); description of his first trip to San Antonio and the results of his eye exam and his unusual eyes (Jan 8 & 9); begins classes on flying and the development of pressure and altitude chambers up to the present, including an actual test run with the pressure chamber, and learning the use and repair of oxygen equipment (Jan 10-11); operating the pressure chamber (Jan 12, 17, 27); his extreme suspicion of his wife over having her photograph taken or possibly being around men (Jan 22, 24, 25, & 27); passing his final exam and officially becoming an Altitude Chamber Technician (Jan 29); adventures with ice skating (Jan 31 & Feb 7); the visit of Chinese officers to the altitude chamber and their description of atrocities of the Japanese against the Chinese people (Feb 4 & 5). The letters end with Burnett still stationed with the 29th Altitude Training Unit in San Antonio, Texas.
